sn55.54:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.
sn55.54:1.2: At that time several mendicants were making a robe for the Buddha, thinking that
sn55.54:1.3: when his robe was finished and the three months of the rains residence had passed the Buddha would set out wandering.
sn55.54:1.4: Mahānāma the Sakyan heard about this.
sn55.54:1.7: Then he went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him that he had heard that the Buddha was leaving. He added,
sn55.54:1.11: “Sir, I haven’t heard and learned it in the presence of the Buddha
sn55.54:1.12: how a wise lay follower should advise another wise lay follower who is sick, suffering, gravely ill.”
sn55.54:2.1: “Mahānāma, a wise lay follower should put at ease another wise lay follower who is sick, suffering, gravely ill with four consolations.
sn55.54:2.3: You have experiential confidence in the Buddha …
sn55.54:2.7: And you have the ethical conduct loved by the noble ones … leading to immersion.’
sn55.54:3.1: When a wise lay follower has put at ease another wise lay follower who is sick, suffering, gravely ill with these four consolations, they should say:
sn55.54:3.2: ‘Are you concerned for your mother and father?’
sn55.54:3.5: ‘But sir, it’s your nature to die.
sn55.54:3.6: Whether or not you are concerned for your mother and father,
sn55.54:3.8: It would be good to give up concern for your mother and father.’
sn55.54:4.2: ‘I have given up concern for my mother and father,’ they should say:
sn55.54:4.3: ‘But are you concerned for your partners and children?’
sn55.54:4.6: ‘But sir, it’s your nature to die.
sn55.54:4.7: Whether or not you are concerned for your partners and children,
sn55.54:4.9: It would be good to give up concern for your partners and children.’
sn55.54:5.2: ‘I have given up concern for my partners and children,’ they should say:
sn55.54:5.3: ‘But are you concerned for the five kinds of human sensual stimulation?’
sn55.54:5.6: ‘Good sir, heavenly sensual pleasures are better than human sensual pleasures.
sn55.54:5.7: It would be good to turn your mind away from human sensual pleasures and fix it on the gods of the four great kings.’
sn55.54:6.2: ‘I have done so,’ they should say:
sn55.54:6.3: ‘Good sir, the gods of the thirty-three are better than the gods of the four great kings …
sn55.54:7.3: Good sir, the gods of Yama …
sn55.54:7.5: the gods who love to imagine …
sn55.54:7.6: the gods who control what is imagined by others …
sn55.54:7.7: the gods of the realm of divinity are better than the gods who control what is imagined by others.
sn55.54:7.8: It would be good to turn your mind away from the gods who control what is imagined by others and fix it on the gods of the realm of divinity.’
sn55.54:7.10: ‘I have done so,’ they should say:
sn55.54:7.11: ‘Good sir, the realm of divinity is impermanent, not lasting, and included within substantial reality.
sn55.54:7.12: It would be good to turn your mind away from the realm of divinity and apply it to the cessation of substantial reality.’
sn55.54:8.3: then there is no difference between a lay follower whose mind is freed in this way and a mendicant whose mind is freed from defilements; that is,
sn55.54:8.4: between the freedom of one and the other.”
